item.title: Ticket #7273 (Deleting a parent category doesn't properly update all child categories) created
item.dc:creator: MtDewVirus
item.description:
When a parent category is deleted, the child categories are not all updated properly.

Steps to reproduce

  1. Create a category titled Parent
  2. Create a category titled Child1 with parent category set as Parent
  3. Create a category titled Child2 with parent category set as Parent
  4. Delete Parent category
  5. Child1 gets updated properly in the database. It no longer has a category parent
  6. Child2 still has the parent set to the deleted Parent category.

Tested with r8302

item.title: Ticket #7248 (Manage Pages - advanced options does not react) closed
item.dc:creator: tbrams
item.description:
fixed:

Just installed the beta 3 release and as the problem persisted, I started disabling plugins one by one and checked the manage/pages issue each time. It ceased to exist when I got around to disabling feedwordpress. Apparently this plugin is not compatible with 2.6

Please close the issue. And sorry for shouting wolf here... everything really run smoothly after I got rid of the plug-in. (If there is a list of incompatible stuff we should add ​http://projects.radgeek.com/feedwordpress/ for now).

Thanks for the prompt response and the quick burst of beta releases.

item.title: Ticket #7272 (Deleting a page parent doesn't properly update all child pages) created
item.dc:creator: MtDewVirus
item.description:
When a page parent is deleted, the child pages are not all updated properly.

Steps to reproduce

  1. Create a page titled Parent
  2. Create a page titled Child1 with parent page set as Parent
  3. Create a page titled Child2 with parent page set as Parent
  4. Delete Parent page
  5. Child1 gets updated properly in the database. It no longer has a page parent
  6. Child2 still has the parent set to the deleted Parent page.

Tested with r8302

item.title: Ticket #7261 (Press This) updated
item.dc:creator: paulhontz
item.description:
One way to potentially get around this is have separate bookmarklets for *good* browsers, and then one for IE.

By killing off the user agent string to see if it's firefox, you can save quite a few characters, and you should be within the 508 char limit.

item.title: Ticket #7261 (Press This) updated
item.dc:creator: paulhontz
item.description:
I think this might have something to do with why the IE 6 bookmarklet doesn't do anything.

​http://blog.seagul.co.uk/articles/2007/12/14/bookmarklet-favelet-limits-in-internet-explorer-6-and-7

item.title: Ticket #7261 (Press This) updated
item.dc:creator: paulhontz
item.description:
Hey ryan, thanks for your help. I haven't been able to get tiny_mce editor to come up, but I think that might just be something on my end.

Also, would it be possible to have an option to automatically cite your source? Meaning that a link could be placed at the bottom of the post that leads directly back to the webpage you "Press This"ed from?

Thanks again!

item.title: Ticket #7262 (Use Firefox 3.5 native offline cache to add "turbo" functionality) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Type, Component changed

Is there any documentation on what, exactly, FF 3.1 will support? I know that the HTML 5 spec on this changed midway through the draft, leading different browsers to support differing functionality...

More info: ​http://www.nczonline.net/blog/2008/5/18/and_so_the_html_5_trouble_begins

item.title: Ticket #7260 (Blogger API is incomplete) closed
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
invalid:

Agreed. That's the new-ish Blogger Data API, which they implemented after Google bought Blogger. The Blogger API that WordPress implements via XML-RPC is the older Blogger API, as found here: ​http://www.blogger.com/developers/api/documentation20.html

WP doesn't support the GData API. It wouldn't make much sense to do so, I think, as that's very Google specific.

item.title: Ticket #7118 (New media uploader uploads files to the wp-admin directory.) updated
item.dc:creator: jleuze
item.description:
Replying to Otto42:

Remove or comment them out. See if that changes anything.

For some unknown reason, last week my blogs started to upload files correctly. This change was spontaneous, I didn't change anything on my end.

I even tried over from scratch with a fresh install of WordPress and a new database, and my uploader still works. Which is a good thing I suppose!

But it is strange, I can only guess that my webhost, Network Solutions, made some adjustment that is causing the uploader to function correctly.

I am sorry, since my problem fixed itself, I won't be able to help you with this bug.

item.title: Ticket #7261 (Press This) updated
item.dc:creator: paulhontz
item.description:
If you don't have any text selected when you click on "Press This", it will automatically put a link in the post with the title (of the site) as the link (example: You are on gmail.com and press the bookmarklet. Your new post would open up with a link that said "Gmail - Inbox (X) - xxxxxx@…".

However, if you have text selected when you press your bookmarklet the whole selection becomes a link. I don't believe this is the intended behavior. To make matters worse, if you then click on the "Photo" tab, the large link converts to plain text and stays like that even if you click back on the "Text" tab

Does this help clarify? I'm using Firefox 3.

however, when I use Safari, or IE7 (the css also appears to be messed up for use with ie7) the editor fails to appear at all. Instead, I see the code (example below) 

<a href='http://www.autoblog.com/2008/07/09/g-power-aims-to-rival-m-with-supercharged-z4/'>a natural choice for anyone who wants a high performance BMW, but that hasn't stopped G-Power from offering go-fast parts for Bimmer ow</a>

Also, when I've tried clicking my bookmarklet in IE6, nothing appears. If I click on the link (that you're suppose to add to favorites), it works fine. If I add it to my list, and try and click on it, it fails to open anything.

item.title: Ticket #7270 (tilde character encoded by mod_proxy creates a redirect loop on login) updated
item.dc:creator: hopson
item.description: Keywords, Version, Milestone changed

item.title: tilde-encoding.patch attached to Ticket #7270
item.dc:creator: hopson

item.title: Ticket #7270 (tilde character encoded by mod_proxy creates a redirect loop on login) created
item.dc:creator: hopson
item.description:
When unix user accounts are frontended by Apache+mod_proxy, the tilde character (~) is encoded as %7E. RFC 2396 states that it does not need to be encoded, and Apache 2.3 has fixed this:

​http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/httpd/httpd/trunk/CHANGES

In wp-includes/pluggable.php, function auth_redirect (line 612 in wordpress 2.5.1): 

wp_redirect(get_option('siteurl') . '/wp-login.php?redirect_to=' . urlencode($_SERVER['REQUEST_URI']));

creates a redirect loop, because REQUEST_URI already contains the decoded %7E, so it is double-encoded, and then fails the path check (against wp_settings('home'); I believe).

The attached patch (for Wordpress 2.5.1) adds a call to urldecode() before urlencode(), to turn the %7E back into tilde.

item.title: Ticket #7269 (Scheduled posts are losing their geocoding) created
item.dc:creator: AndreasMoser
item.description:
If I schedule a post I lose the geotagging informations.

I did the following checks

  • Create post, with geotagging information, publish date in future

--- a new entry gets generated in the table wp_postmeta with the meta_key _geo_location

  • Reopen post - geotagging infos are still there (also in the table)
  • Date of publish reached
  • Post is published without the geotagging infos

--- the entry in the table wp_postmeta is gone

item.title: Ticket #6199 (TinyMCE fails to detect some Mac keyboard combos) updated
item.dc:creator: MattyRob
item.description:
Summary changed

I suspect that this is a bug in TinyMCE and not WordPress.

To reproduce: Open a "Write Post" page Enter some text into the document Change the focus off the textarea Select text using different methods: Mouse + drag works Ctrl+A works Shift + arrow keys works

Command as a modifier key and arrows doesn't work, most likely because TinyMCE does not detect the modifier on Mac of pressing Command. I will confirm my suspicions by trying out TinyMCE directly on the Moxiecode site from my Mac later and close this ticket as wontfix and log it with TinyMCE if I'm right.

item.title: Ticket #5647 (class-phpmailer.php wrongly assumes sendmail compatibility) closed
item.dc:creator: MattyRob
item.description:
wontfix:

mail() is used as the default so this will only affect users of plugins that override the default function. I'm not sure how this could be fixed to ensure 100% compatibility with all possible server scenarios. Some of this will have to fall back to end users to ensure a correctly configured server.

item.title: Ticket #7268 (Comments with ' or " in are treated as spam) created
item.dc:creator: NigelDunn
item.description:
On one site we've had a number of comments being automatically classed as spam where the user has included the character ' (& also possibly "). These are being converted into ' (when I've used print_r to put create the body text for wp_mail they're actually \') and then are being flagged as spam by wp_blacklist_check.

If I amend line 415 of wp-includes/comment.php to check for character 39 as well then the same comment is added into the comment list for approval.

No extra spam filters/plugins have been included on the site, it's just using the default processing supplied by WP 2.5.1. Nothing has been added to the comment blacklist setting in Settings->Discussion

The site is running on a shared Unix server & the hosting company have switched off phpInfo(), so unfortunately I can't supply the settings there.

item.description: Prevent category looping. Props tellyworth. fixes #7267

item.title: prevent-category-looping-r8296.patch attached to Ticket #7267
item.dc:creator: tellyworth

item.title: Ticket #7267 (Infinite recursion in get_category_parents() and _children()) created
item.dc:creator: tellyworth
item.description:
These two functions can get stuck in a recursion loop if there's an indirect category hierarchy loop like A -> B -> C -> A.

The patch keeps track of traversed IDs and prevents repetition - there's a name for the algorithm but it escapes me. It increases memory usage but probably not too much - certainly less than infinite recursion does.

item.dc:creator: matt
item.description: Ajax Deleting an object that's already been deleted should silently succeed. Hat tip: mdawaffe. Fixes #7264.

item.title: 7264.diff attached to Ticket #7264
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe

item.title: Ticket #7264 (Ajax Deleting an object that's already been deleted should silently succeed) created
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description:
When AJAX deleting a comment, say, that has just been deleted by another user, WP throws the comment back at you in red and says "An unidentified error has occurred".

Almost all the time when that error happens, it's because the comment you're trying to delete is already gone... so it's not really error worthy.

Attached checks to see if to-be-deleted objects are already gone and silently ajax returns "success" when deleted.

Also checks to see if the current comment status is the same as the requested comment status and silently succeeds there as well.

item.title: Ticket #7263 (Incorrect Error Message When Users Attempt to Add API Key using WP Stats) created
item.dc:creator: bubel
item.description:
Incorrect Error Message When Users Attempt to Add API Key of a user who is not on the blog's access list.

When a user attempts to add the API key of another user who is not on the blog's access list, an incorrect error message is displayed.

For instance, if user A wanted to add user B's API Key to a blog, an error message will display is user B is not on the blog's access list. However, the error message will read:

Error from last API Key attempt: The owner of that API Key (user A) is not on the access list for this blog (blog_id_goes_here). To be added to the access list, you must contact support.

The error message should display user B instead of user A.

item.title: Changeset [8287]: crazyhorse: cats, tags, time changes
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description: crazyhorse: cats, tags, time changes

item.title: Ticket #7262 (Use Firefox 3.5 native offline cache to add "turbo" functionality) created
item.dc:creator: mfinkle
item.description:
Recent Wordpress releases add a "turbo" feature that uses Gears local cache to store many static resources locally and increases the overal performance of the admin panel.

Firefox 3.1 will support the same functionality natively, without the need for a plugin. WordPress could streamline it's user experience and minimize dependencies if it used the new Firefox feature.

​http://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Offline_resources_in_Firefox discusses how the offline resources work in Firefox. Firefox 3.0 did not support enough of the HTML5 offline spec to enable this feature for WordPress, but Firefox 3.1 will and the feature will appear in nightly versions of Firefox 3.1 soon.

item.title: Ticket #7259 (Tag Cloud doesn't allow tags to wrap between lines) created
item.dc:creator: MtDewVirus
item.description: When a tag has spaces in it, the tag cloud replaces them with  . This causes layout problems because the tag doesn't wrap between lines and spill out over the sidebar.
